questions.question: A core purpose of insurance regulation is to:
options: Protect consumers and maintain confidence in the financial system
questions.correctAnswer: Protect consumers and maintain confidence in the financial system
questions.explanation: Consumer protection and market confidence are central aims of regulation.

questions.question: Prudential regulation focuses primarily on:
options: The safety and financial soundness of insurers
questions.correctAnswer: The safety and financial soundness of insurers
questions.explanation: Market conduct regulation focuses on fair dealing with customers.

questions.question: Typical oversight functions of a regulator include regulation, authorisation, supervision, surveillance and:
questions.explanation: Regulators can sanction or refer breaches for prosecution.

questions.question: The International Association of Insurance Supervisors (IAIS) primarily:
options: Sets legally binding rules for all countries
Develops principles, standards and guidance for supervision
questions.correctAnswer: Develops principles, standards and guidance for supervision
questions.explanation: IAIS provides international supervisory standards, not binding law.

questions.question: Capital adequacy frameworks are intended to:
options: Ensure every claim is paid within 24 hours
Ensure insurers can meet obligations even under stress
questions.correctAnswer: Ensure insurers can meet obligations even under stress
questions.explanation: Capital buffers and solvency control levels underpin financial resilience.

questions.question: Customer Due Diligence (CDD) measures generally include:
options: Identifying and verifying customers and beneficial owners, and ongoing monitoring
questions.correctAnswer: Identifying and verifying customers and beneficial owners, and ongoing monitoring
questions.explanation: CDD is a core AML/CTF control.

questions.question: Which is the correct order of the three stages of money laundering?
questions.explanation: Funds enter the system (placement), are obscured (layering), then returned as 'clean' (integration).

questions.question: Examples of insurance fraud can include:
questions.explanation: Fraud categories are broad; controls include detection, investigation, and prevention frameworks.

questions.question: From a market conduct perspective, regulators may require:
options: Adequate disclosure, dispute resolution schemes, and fair treatment of customers
questions.correctAnswer: Adequate disclosure, dispute resolution schemes, and fair treatment of customers
questions.explanation: These tools promote fair dealing and informed choices.

questions.question: The global AML/CTF standard-setting body is the ________.
questions.explanation: FATF issues recommendations and mutual evaluations through a global network.

flashcards.definition: Prudential = financial soundness; Conduct = fair treatment of customers.
International standard-setter for insurance supervision (principles, standards, guidance).
Thresholds triggering supervisory intervention to protect policyholders.
